content: The "National Commission on Professional Baseball Act of 1995" establishes the National Commission on Professional Baseball, referred to as the "Commission," with defined membership. The National Commission on Professional Baseball, known as the "Commission," consists of seven members appointed by the President. Members are appointed after consultations with various baseball stakeholders and government officials. The President designates one member as the Chairman of the Commission. The Commission members serve a five-year term, extendable by Congress. A majority constitutes a quorum, with at least three members present for meetings. Appointments must be made within sixty days, and the first meeting within ninety days of enactment. The Commission members serve a five-year term, extendable by Congress, with a majority constituting a quorum for meetings. Appointments must be made within sixty days, and if a member is unable to serve, a new member will be appointed within forty-five days to serve the remainder of the term. All Commission meetings and hearings are open to the public. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission oversees and investigates various aspects of major league baseball and minor league baseball, intervening in negotiations, setting ticket prices, managing team expansion/relocation, stadium requirements, player contracts, TV broadcast rights, and merchandise licensing. The Commission oversees licensing, marketing, and revenue sharing in baseball. It also conducts arbitration and mediation for labor disputes and conflicts between MLB and team owners. The Commission has powers related to overseeing licensing, marketing, revenue sharing, arbitration, and mediation in baseball. The Commission, or a panel of at least three members, can hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, courts, and relevant parties in baseball, and issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence. The Commission can hold hearings, gather information, and issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence related to investigations. Witnesses may be required to appear and produce evidence within the judicial district. If a person refuses to obey a subpoena, a court may order them to appear before the Commission. The Commission can issue subpoenas for witness testimony and evidence related to investigations. Failure to obey the court order may result in contempt of court. Subpoenas must be served in accordance with the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Process serving can be done in the judicial district where the person resides or can be found. The Commission can take action if an act or practice of Major League Baseball is not in the public interest. The Commission has the authority to issue orders to temporarily stay acts or practices in baseball, bring civil actions to enjoin such acts, and obtain temporary restraining orders or injunctions if it is in the public interest. The Administrator of General oversees facilities and support services. The Commission has the authority to request facilities and support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. They can also make expenditures and enter into contracts for necessary supplies and services, limited to appropriated funds. The Commission has the authority to request facilities and support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis. They can also make expenditures and enter into contracts for necessary supplies and services, limited to appropriated funds. Additionally, the Commission may use the United States mails in the same manner and under the same conditions as other Federal departments and agencies of the United States. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION OF THE COMMISSION. Each member of the Commission is a full-time Federal employee and receives an annual rate of basic pay at level II of the Executive Schedule. Members are also reimbursed for necessary expenses. SEC. 7. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. SEC. 7. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Chairman can appoint up to ten staff members and set their compensation. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Commission will study the antitrust exemption for Major League Baseball, analyzing its effects on players, teams, fans, and local governments. This includes examining the possible impacts of continuing or modifying the exemption. This could involve proposals for eliminating or partially eliminating the antitrust exemption. The Commission will study the antitrust exemption for Major League Baseball, analyzing its effects on players, teams, fans, and local governments. This could involve proposals for eliminating or partially eliminating the antitrust exemption, with protections for existing contractual relationships between major league and minor league baseball teams. A report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations will be submitted to Congress three years after the Act's enactment. The Commission will study the antitrust exemption for Major League Baseball and make recommendations for potential legislation modifications. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION AND FEES. Authorization is granted to appropriate necessary funds for this title, with a limit not exceeding funds available under subsection (b). Major League Baseball must pay a fee to the Treasury of the United States annually, based on team revenues, with exemptions possible upon Commission approval. Payment terms are to be determined in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury. Payment of fees under this subsection shall be made annually for the duration of the Act, with consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury and Major League Baseball. Additional years of payment will be determined by Congress. The duties and powers of the Commission outlined in this Act will end five years after enactment, unless Congress extends them. The Act will come into effect on the date of enactment.
